author: NewsWire
text: A U.S. official has alleged wrongdoing by U.S. spy chief Tulsi Gabbard in a complaint that is so highly classified it has sparked months of wrangling over how to share it with Congress, according to people familiar with the matter.
aiSummary: A classified whistleblower complaint alleging misconduct by the director of national intelligence has been withheld from Congress for months over secrecy and privilege disputes, raising concerns that national security classification may be delaying or blocking oversight.

replies.author: CivicsNerd
replies.text: TRANSLATION: Tulsi Gabbard is exposing actual vote fraud, and is close to exposing more, so us, and our friends are getting scared and need to do some misdirection.

replies.author: HistoryBuff
replies.text: More likely selling US intel to Russia.

replies.author: PatriotTex
replies.text: That sounds bad

replies.author: MilkshakeMan
replies.text: Literally all of us at home already know what it is, she is a Russia asset.

replies.author: PolicyWonk
replies.text: If it’s classified, Congress still needs a process for oversight. Otherwise classification becomes a shield.

replies.author: DataDiver
replies.text: What’s the timeline here—when was the complaint filed vs when oversight committees were notified?

replies.author: LibertyLens
replies.text: Feels like we keep learning about these things only after months of internal fighting.

replies.author: SkepticalSam
replies.text: Hard to judge without specifics. But the secrecy wrangling is the story in itself.

replies.author: CivicProcess
replies.text: There should be a standard secure reading room protocol so these disputes don’t stall indefinitely.

replies.author: NatSecNina
replies.text: If this involves sources/methods, it’s complicated. But oversight still has to happen.

replies.author: ThreadReader
replies.text: Anyone have a reliable breakdown of what’s alleged (without speculation)?

replies.author: CapitolWatch
replies.text: The bigger issue is whether privilege claims can override lawful congressional review.

author: PoliticsDaily
text: Trump to close Kennedy Center for two years, amid falling ticket sales and a growing list of performer cancellations, sparking more controversy over DC venue
aiSummary: Trump plans to close the Kennedy Center for two years following artist boycotts and falling attendance after his takeover of its board and branding. Critics note the venue underwent a $250M renovation in 2019 and question whether “dilapidation” claims mask governance and backlash issues.

replies.author: TruthGuard
replies.text: Trump wants to own every building in America and have his name on every bulding in America

replies.author: Justice4All
replies.text: Libs heads explode in...3...2...1

replies.author: Watcher
replies.text: Trump closes Kennedy Center amidst declining visitation due to his marking the edifice with his own name. Trump believes in this way he can cover up the public rejection of his shameful desecration of a once popular and honorable memorial to JFK.

replies.author: ArtsFanDC
replies.text: Two years is a long time to shut down a cultural venue. What’s the actual renovation plan?

replies.author: BudgetHawk
replies.text: If sales are down, closing removes revenue entirely. Curious what the financial model is.

replies.author: StageDoor
replies.text: Performers cancel when they don’t trust governance. Fix governance first.

replies.author: CivicArts
replies.text: DC already struggles with arts funding—this will ripple to staff and local gigs.

replies.author: RenovationNerd
replies.text: Wasn’t there a major renovation not that long ago? Confused about the 'dilapidated' claim.

replies.author: TicketTally
replies.text: Attendance trends matter, but boycotts are also a signal. Both can be true.

replies.author: NeutralObserver
replies.text: This story feels like politics colliding with an institution that needs stability.

replies.author: OperaSeat12
replies.text: I just want great shows and predictable seasons. Leadership drama ruins programming.

replies.author: DCResident
replies.text: Staff and vendors will take the hit long before any politician does.

author: wowsomuchpolitics
text: House Speaker Mike Johnson (R-Louisiana) said that he is “confident” he will have enough support from Republicans in the House conference to end the partial government shutdown by Tuesday.
aiSummary: The government shutdown hinges on funding for DHS after a controversial ICE operation, with Democrats demanding limits like body cameras and warrants. Speaker Mike Johnson says reopening depends on near-total GOP unity, highlighting how immigration enforcement drives shutdowns under narrow majorities.

replies.author: Ant Hooper
replies.text: Don’t cave to the Left. Hold fast to what is right.

replies.author: Andreas
replies.text: Johnson is on the way out... Republicans are starting to run after the Texas loss on Saturday.

replies.author: JimBoot
replies.text: Mike Johnson's confidence in knowing what his caucus will do is as reliable as his confidence in knowing what unhinged nonsense Trump will post online at 2am on any given day.

replies.author: FedWorker
replies.text: Shutdown brinkmanship hits paychecks and services. Please just vote on clean funding.

replies.author: Proceduralist
replies.text: If they have the votes, do it now. Announcing confidence doesn’t reopen agencies.

replies.author: CSpanJunkie
replies.text: Curious what the actual sticking point language is. The details always matter.

replies.author: BudgetWatcher
replies.text: We do this every year and still act surprised. It’s exhausting.

replies.author: UnionRep
replies.text: Federal contractors get hurt too and often have fewer protections than employees.

replies.author: PolicyGrad
replies.text: Even short shutdowns add costs. The 'savings' argument is a myth in practice.

replies.author: NewsSkimmer
replies.text: Tuesday feels like a talking point. What changed since yesterday?

replies.author: CautiousCentrist
replies.text: Both sides should stop tying unrelated policy demands to funding the basics.

replies.author: NumbersGuy
replies.text: Markets shrug until the pain is visible, then everyone panics. Predictable cycle.

author: USPolitics
text: A federal judge ruled that 5-year-old Liam Conejo Ramos, detained by ICE alongside his father, should not remain in federal custody. Data and analysis suggest ICE is increasingly detaining young children amid President Trump’s mass deportation efforts.
aiSummary: A federal judge ordered the release of a five-year-old asylum-seeking child and his father, criticizing ICE tactics as quota-driven rather than humanitarian. The case has intensified scrutiny of child detention practices amid pending asylum claims.

replies.author: RFKStan
replies.text: I hope his family sues for every penny they can get. Poor kid. I hope he isn’t totally scarred for life from this experience

replies.author: Heritage83
replies.text: He belongs with his family, and his family belongs in their home country, NOT HERE.

replies.author: NYCInsider
replies.text: MAGA is furious kids are being released from jail

replies.author: EmmaB
replies.text: Families should stay together no matter what

replies.author: LegalEagle
replies.text: Judges stepping in usually means the process broke down somewhere. The child’s welfare should be paramount.

replies.author: CaseReader
replies.text: Does anyone have the actual ruling text or a reputable summary of the judge’s reasoning?

replies.author: HumanRights
replies.text: Detaining young children should be a last resort with strict safeguards.

replies.author: BorderPolicy
replies.text: Regardless of politics, clear standards and accountability would reduce abuse.

replies.author: SocialWorker
replies.text: Even short detention can be traumatic at that age. Support services matter.

replies.author: CivicDebate
replies.text: We need enforcement that doesn’t create irreversible harm to kids.

replies.author: ProcessMatters
replies.text: If data show an increase, oversight should ask why and whether policy changed.

replies.author: LocalReporter
replies.text: Stories like this get lost in the aggregate. The human impact is real.
